STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 13, 2025
Jennifer Lynn Trotter
Guiding Harbor
525 E Huron River Dr.
Belleville MI, 48111-3665
Re: License #: CB820201144
Dear Ms. Trotter:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
5/6/2025. A exit confernce was held with your agency on 5/12/2025. Due to the violations
of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
DCWL Licensing Consultant
Enclosure
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB820201144
Licensee Group Organization: Girlstown Foundation
Licensee Designee: Jennifer Lynn Trotter
Chief Administrator: Jennifer Lynn Trotter
Name of Agency: GUIDING HARBOR
Agency Address: 525 E HURON RIVER DR
BELLEVILLE, MI 48111-3665
Agency Telephone #: 7346977242
Original Issuance Date: 05/20/1989
Service Types: Certify foster homes for license, Evaluate
Applicants for adoption, Place children for
adoption, Place children in foster home,
Supervise Independent Living
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION
A. Consultant
Date(s) of On-site Inspection: 4/28/25, 4/29/25, 5/1/25
Total No. Of No. of
Records Records
Reviewed
Current licensed foster homes 50 6
Homes pending licensure 6 3
Foster homes closed since the last inspection 2 2
Foster homes borrowed since the last inspection 2 2
Special Investigations in foster homes since last inspection 4 3
Incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect
in foster care since last inspection 0 0
Incidents of substantiated corporal punishment in foster care
since last inspection 0 0
Children receiving direct foster care case management
(placement in foster homes, parental home,
relative homes, CCI, hospital, etc.) 50 6
Children discharged from care during this period 21 4
Youth in independent living placement 9 3
Youth discharged from an independent living placement
since the last inspection 4 4
Applicants approved for adoption since the last inspection 13 4
Applicants denied for adoption since the last inspection 1 1
Closed child adoption cases since the last inspection 6 3
Open child adoption cases 16 4
Current employees who have worked at the facility for:
More than a year 12 5
Less than a year 10 10
Persons Interviewed:
Licensing Staff 1
Foster Care Staff 1
Adoption Staff 1
Supervisory Staff 2
Administrative Staff 2
2

B. Analyst
Total No. No. Visited
Licensed foster homes 12 3
Unlicensed relative homes 21 3
Number of persons interviewed:
Foster Parents 3
Foster Children 5
Relatives 3
Others (identify person interviewed by role) 0
III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12202 Policy and procedures.
(1) An agency shall have and follow written policies and
procedures for all the areas of foster care services as
provided in R400.12203 to R 400.12214.
The agency requires its employees to complete annual ICHATs and central registry
clearances. Six of six employee records reviewed where the employee had been
employed over one year showed the respective employee's annual ICHAT was
completed after its annual due date; and two of the six employee records reviewed
showed the central record clearance was completed after its annual due date.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months
after the staff member assumes his or her current
responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a written
evaluation must be conducted every 12 months.
Three of 10 new employee records reviewed showed the employee's 6-month's
performance evaluation was completed after the employee's respective 11/1/2024
1/23/2025 and 1/23/2025 due date.
2

CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation must include a determination
and assessment of all the following:
(b) Family functioning and interrelationships as
determined by observation of, and interviews with, each
member of the household and each social service worker
who has had children placed in the home during the last
licensing period.
Two of five open foster home records reviewed, one did not show an interview or
observation of a child in the foster home. The second did not show an interview of
an adult household member.
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by
another agency the borrowing agency shall have a
record containing all the following:
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement signed
by the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
Two of two borrowed home records reviewed showed the foster parent/agency
agreement was completed/signed after the date the child was placed with the
agency and the foster home was borrowed.
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by
another agency the borrowing agency shall have a
record containing all the following:
(f) Documentation that the foster parent has received
orientation to the policies of the borrowing agency.
Two of two borrowed home records reviewed showed the foster parent’s orientation
to the agency's policies occurred after the date the child was placed with the agency
and the foster home was borrowed.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
3

(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all
the following information:
(e) Conclusions regarding licensing rules compliance or
noncompliance based on the findings of fact.
One of three special evaluation records reviewed the evaluation showed the foster
father admitted to spanking the child, but a rule violation to the foster home was not
documented in the special evaluation. It is noted at the exit conference the agency
reported this foster home has closed.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(f) A dental re-examination must be obtained at least
every 9 months, unless a greater frequency is indicated.
Two of six open foster child records reviewed showed the child’s 9-month's dental
examination was completed after its 10/3/2024 and 1/10/2025 respective due date.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
Three of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation that at
the time of placement the caregiver was provided information related to if there were
any known behaviors for the child.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 8/9/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
4

(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
Two of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation that at
the time of placement the caregiver was provided information related to the
circumstances necessitating placement of the child.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 8/9/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(c) Available known information about the child's health.
Two of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation the
caregiver was provided information related to the child's health at the time of
placement.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 8/9/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
Two of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation that at
the time of placement the caregiver was provided information related to if there was
any history of abuse or neglect for the child.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 8/9/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
5

(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors
relating to the care of the child.
Two of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation that at
the time of placement the caregiver was provided information related any known
emotional and psychological factors relating to the care of the child.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 8/9/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents
and the foster parents in the development of service
plans to enable the parent or parents and foster parents
to understand the plan for the child and the parents' and
the foster parent's role in assisting the agency in carrying
out the plan. An agency shall give a copy to and review
the parent-agency treatment plan with the parent or
parents and foster parents. The agency must inform the
parent or parents and foster parent that the information
in the parent-agency treatment plan and any other
information about the child and the child's family is
confidential.
Two of six open foster child records reviewed; one record did not show
documentation that two-treatment plans were signed timely by all required parties.
The second child's record did not show documentation the caregiver signed the
child's 7/6/2024-10/2/2024 treatment plan timely.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 8/9/2025, cited under FOM 722-8D.
Interim 2023, CAP approved 7/25/23, cited under FOM 7228-D.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), must include all the following
information:
6

(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404(4).
Three of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of the
child's placement criteria in the child’s initial services, as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 8/9/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12507 Medical, dental and mental health care.
(1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent
living receives any needed medical, dental, and mental
health care as required in R 400.12413. Medical, dental,
and mental health care provided must be documented in
the youth's record.
Two of three open independent living youth records reviewed, one did not show
documentation of a dental exam for the youth which was due by 1/14/2025. The
second showed the youth's medical exam which was due by 12/21/2024 was
completed late on 1/7/2025.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 8/9/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement.
(1) There must be a mutual agreement between the
youth and the agency specifying all the following:
(a) The responsibilities of the agency and the youth.
One of three open independent living youth records reviewed did not show an initial
mutual agreement signed by the youth and agency.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 8/9/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination.
(1) When an agency terminates its independent living
services for a youth, the agency shall document all the
following information in the case record within 30
calendar days of termination of its services:
7

(c) A summary of the services provided during care and
the needs that remain to be met.
Two of three closed independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of the summary of service provided during care and the needs that
remain to be met, as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim 2023, CAP approved 7/25/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination.
(1) When an agency terminates its independent living
services for a youth, the agency shall document all the
following information in the case record within 30
calendar days of termination of its services:
(d) Provision for any follow-up services.
Two of three closed independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of whether there was any provision for follow-up services, as
required by the rule.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim 2023, CAP approved 7/25/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a
written adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family
signing an adoption application and prior to approving a
family for adoption.
One of four adoptive family evaluations reviewed showed the family's adoption
evaluation was not completed within 90 days of the application date, as required by
the rule.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 8/9/2024
Interim 2023, CAP approved 7/25/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12607 Agency recommendation.
8

(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption
with a signed and dated copy of the evaluation and
recommendation upon its completion.
One of four adoptive family evaluations reviewed did not show documentation that
the family's adoption evaluation was provided upon its completion.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim 2023, CAP approved 7/25/2023.
ACT 116- 722.120 Investigation, inspection, and examination of
conditions, books, records, and reports; access by
department, bureau of fire services, or local authorities;
records; report; forms; confidentiality; disclosure of
information; availability of confidential records; child
information cards to be provided to department; failure
of licensee to cooperate with investigation, inspection, or
examination.
(3) A licensee shall keep the records the department
prescribes regarding each child in its control and care and
shall report to the department, when requested, the facts the
department requires with reference to the children upon
forms furnished by the department. Except as otherwise
provided in this subsection and subsection (4), records
regarding children and facts compiled about children and
their parents and relatives are confidential and disclosure of
this information shall be properly safeguarded by the
childcare organization, the department, and any other entity
in possession of the information. Records that are
confidential under this section are available to both of the
following:
One of three special evaluation records reviewed showed children protective services
(CPS) language in the report showing CPS involvement in the investigation, in violation of
this rule.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim 2023, CAP approved 7/25/23.
CPA Rule 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 member of the household must have training in
an maintain a current certification in first aid and
cardiopulmonary resuscitation from the American Heart
9

Association or the American Red Cross or other institution
approved by the department.
One of five open foster home records reviewed showed the foster parents updated CPR
and first aid certification was completed late.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 8/9/2024.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• R400.12418(3) & R400.12509(3)(o) Development of service plans &
Independent living record: The agency was apprised its 30-day report shall
clearly and consistently indicate why case responsibility changed and whether
there are any modifications to the existing service plan.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• R400.12418(3) & R400.12509(3)(o) Development of service plans &
Independent living record: The agency was advised adding a heading like
why case responsibility changed and modifications to the existing service plan
to their 30-day report template may aid it in showing clear and consistent
compliance to the rule.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. Although this inspection found a foster parent spanked a youth and was
found in compliance which is not consistent with findings of fact and will be
addressed in the agency’s corrective action plan. The foster home license is
closed.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
During this licensing inspection period the agency submitted one acceptable
corrective action plans. That corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2024
Renewal inspection where it was found in violation of 25 rule violations. During this
2025 Interim 11 violations were repeat violations from the 2024 Renewal
inspection; and 6 are repeat violations from the 2023 Interim inspection. The
agency’s corrective action plan compliance around the 11 rule violations is as
follows: the number of individual cases cited decreased by 1 related to three rule
violations; decreased by 2 related to one rule violation; increased by 1 related to
10

five rule violations; and increased by 2 related to two rule violations. With regards
to the 6-repeat violation from the 2023 Interim inspection; the number of individual
cases cited increased by 1 related to two rule violations, remained the same
related to two rule violation; and decreased by 2 related to two rule violations. The
agency contributed various repeat violations to their staff still learning how to
better organize their work; and the corrective action was not approved until August
2024, which in turn delayed in its implementation.
A review of the agency’s 2024 Renewal corrective action plan showed the agency
has implemented all aspects of the corrective plan. That implementation did not
result in complete compliance of all licensing rules during this inspection. The
agency reported further corrective action planning is now occurring via quarterly
meetings on rule issues, as they strive for compliance to all rules.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted a chief administrator’s (CA) report dated 5/1/2025. The CA
report indicated the bulk of its past non-compliance were due to report timeliness
and accuracy of forms. The CA further indicated that staff are still learning how to
organize their work to get their work completed timely. The CA reported as a
result of the corrective action plan (CAP), training was provided to staff to help
them better understand policies and procedures. Also, they learned after the fact
that some of their corrective action plan’s action steps and verifications were not
written in a way that were verifiable. Additionally, the CA reported the agency was
working to implement better tracking of reports; and supervisors were
implementing quarterly CAP reviews to ensure for oversight and compliance
tracking.
The CA identified the agency’s strengths as their improvement in staff retention;
implementation of case contact meeting which has helped with improvement of
various key performance indicators; and their use of a case aide related to
reminders and transportation with respect to medical and dental examinations.
Areas of focus identified by the CA were more timely signatures on treatment
plans for service plans with the aid of electronic software, and timeliness of action
summaries.
The agency is advised to continue all it efforts to ensure for greater rule
compliance.
Financial Overview
The agency submitted a 2025 annual foster care and adoption budget; as well as
a copy of its 12/31/2023 independent financial audit. A review of these documents
did not show indications of any notable areas of concern.
Staff and Youth Interviews
In addition to a discussion with the chief administrator, program manager,
licensing/adoption supervisor, and foster care supervisor, I interviewed the
supervisor of independent living youth advocates, a foster care worker, a licensing
11

worker, adoption worker, and independent living youth advocate. The staff
interviewed reported good, strong, agency communication; teamwork; caring,
supportive managerial staff who hear the staff; flexibility around staff schedules,
and the agency always striving to improve amongst the agency’s strengths. Areas
of growth reported, related the agency seeking to gain more information on new
cases at the time the referral is accepted, dress code issues, and greater
organization of paperwork within the independent living house.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A tour of the agency’s office did not reveal any concerns or safety issues. The
agency appears to have sufficient equipment for its staff, and agency records are
securely stored.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There was one identified safety alert:
Safety Alert: The safety of the child and home could not be assessed.
Resolution: A special evaluation was opened on the foster home on 3/20/2025. The
agency visited the foster home on 3/20/2025 and no concerns were noted. The youth
in the home was interviewed and was reported as happy and safe. The special
evaluation on the home was targeted to be completed by 5/4/2025.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
June 12, 2025
________________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
June 13, 2025
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
12
